DEB Stylized Fact: All organisms metabolize energy according to similar laws: there are reserves, structure, and energy flow.
Growth and development are discrete phases, where energy is first used for growth and maintenance, and only after reaching a certain level of maturation for reproduction.
Reserves and structure have different chemical compositions: reserve is homeostatic (chemically constant), while structure composition can change.
All cells have the same reserve density per unit volume when in good condition.
Structure maintenance consumes energy proportional to structure mass, not reserves.
Synthesis of new structure requires both reserve and energy from reserves for synthetic processes.
Metabolic cycles are connected through common metabolites such as ATP, NADH, and CoA derivatives.
Specific energy density in reserves is constant across all organism species.
Structure has lower energy density than reserves, which explains different roles.
All metabolic transformations follow the principle of mass and energy conservation.
Energy allocation follows a strict hierarchy: maintenance first, then growth, then reproduction.
Reserve dynamics are governed by first-order kinetics with species-specific parameters.
Structural mass cannot decrease except through damage or aging processes.
Energy conversion efficiency from reserves to structure is species-specific but constant.
All organisms use the same fundamental energy currency (ATP) regardless of complexity.
Metabolic overhead costs are proportional to metabolic rate across all organisms.
Energy storage capacity is limited by physical and chemical constraints of reserve compounds.
Maintenance costs increase with structural complexity and specialization.
Energy flux through an organism must balance inputs and outputs at steady state.
Reserve composition reflects the nutritional history and quality of consumed food.
Structural proteins have longer turnover times than metabolic enzymes.
Energy mobilization from reserves follows enzyme kinetics and substrate availability.
Metabolic pathways are conserved across taxa with similar energy requirements.
Cellular energy demand determines the rate of reserve utilization.
Structure formation requires specific amino acid compositions and cofactors.
Energy losses through heat production are unavoidable in all metabolic processes.
Reserve depletion triggers metabolic adjustments to reduce energy expenditure.
Structural damage accumulation increases maintenance energy requirements over time.
Energy conversion efficiency decreases with increasing metabolic rate.
All organisms maintain energy homeostasis through feedback mechanisms.
Reserve synthesis requires energy investment beyond the energy content of reserves.
Metabolic rate scales with active biomass, not total biomass including reserves.
Energy allocation patterns are genetically determined but environmentally modulated.
Structural maintenance involves both protein synthesis and damage repair mechanisms.
Reserve quality affects energy yield and metabolic efficiency of utilization.
Energy flow patterns determine the maximum sustainable growth rate of organisms.
Metabolic flexibility allows organisms to switch between different energy sources.
Structure-specific maintenance costs vary with tissue type and metabolic activity.
Energy storage forms (lipids, carbohydrates, proteins) have distinct mobilization kinetics.
Metabolic coordination requires signaling molecules that consume energy themselves.
Reserve compartmentalization allows for specialized energy allocation strategies.
Energy investment in maintenance prevents structural degradation and functional decline.
Metabolic networks exhibit redundancy that provides robustness against perturbations.
Structure formation follows template-directed processes requiring energy input.
Energy balance determines whether an organism is in anabolic or catabolic state.
Reserve dynamics respond to environmental conditions with characteristic time lags.
Structural complexity limits the maximum efficiency of energy utilization.
Energy allocation trade-offs constrain simultaneous investment in multiple functions.
Metabolic rate adjustment mechanisms operate on different temporal scales.
Reserve mobilization patterns reflect the energetic priorities of different life stages.
Energy conversion steps involve intermediate metabolites with specific functions.
Structural maintenance requirements increase with environmental stress exposure.
Reserve synthesis rates are limited by enzyme capacity and substrate availability.
Energy allocation efficiency improves with optimal nutrient ratios in food.
Metabolic pathways exhibit saturation kinetics at high substrate concentrations.
Structure formation requires coordination between multiple biosynthetic pathways.
Energy storage capacity scales with organism size but not proportionally.
Reserve composition changes systematically during different metabolic states.
Maintenance energy allocation prevents accumulation of cellular damage.
Energy flow patterns determine the temporal dynamics of growth and development.
Metabolic efficiency varies with the complexity of biosynthetic requirements.
Reserve utilization patterns reflect genetic programming and environmental adaptation.
Energy conversion processes generate byproducts that require disposal or recycling.
Structural maintenance involves quality control mechanisms that consume energy.
Reserve mobilization rates adapt to match energy demand patterns.
Energy allocation strategies reflect evolutionary optimization under constraints.
Metabolic coordination requires information transfer that has energetic costs.
Structure formation efficiency depends on the availability of building blocks.
Energy balance fluctuations trigger homeostatic responses to maintain stability.
Reserve dynamics exhibit hysteresis effects due to storage and mobilization kinetics.
Metabolic network topology determines energy flow patterns and efficiency.
Structural maintenance costs increase with the degree of cellular specialization.
Energy allocation patterns change systematically throughout the life cycle.

Maintenance energy requirements scale with the complexity of regulatory systems.
Energy conversion efficiency is constrained by thermodynamic limits.
Metabolic flexibility requires investment in multiple enzyme systems.
Structural integrity maintenance becomes more costly with increasing organism age.
